Or it's because evolution decided it makes sense for animals who normally sleep at night to sleep less during a full moon, when the naturally nocturnal hunters can see even better.

Seems logical that it would improve your odds of not becoming a late night dinner.

snippet.textDisplay: The hypothesis about epileptic seizures being more common when it's dark outside should be easy to test by looking at seizure rates in the wintertime versus the summertime in parts of the world close to the polar circle. In Scandinavia for instance, depending on how close to the polar circle you are you get little or no sunlight in the winter, and little or no darkness in the summer. So if the hypothesis is true then epileptic seizures should be more common in the winter in those parts of the world.
snippet.textOriginal: The hypothesis about epileptic seizures being more common when it's dark outside should be easy to test by looking at seizure rates in the wintertime versus the summertime in parts of the world close to the polar circle. In Scandinavia for instance, depending on how close to the polar circle you are you get little or no sunlight in the winter, and little or no darkness in the summer. So if the hypothesis is true then epileptic seizures should be more common in the winter in those parts of the world.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wonder if humans menstrual cycles are a similar length to the lunar one not because the moon is directly affecting the length, but because early women who were able to keep track of their cycles based on phases of the moon were at some selective advantage. That'd explain why the length matches, but no particular phase of the moon correlates to menstruation specifically.


ex: Women whose cycles matched the length of the lunar cycle were more easily able to predict when they were likely to conceive, Women who knew when they were likely to conceive could avoid having kids during hard times, having fewer kids means better survival outcomes for the children she does have, leading to more women being born with a roughly lunar length cycle.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wonder if humans menstrual cycles are a similar length to the lunar one not because the moon is directly affecting the length, but because early women who were able to keep track of their cycles based on phases of the moon were at some selective advantage. That'd explain why the length matches, but no particular phase of the moon correlates to menstruation specifically.


ex: Women whose cycles matched the length of the lunar cycle were more easily able to predict when they were likely to conceive, Women who knew when they were likely to conceive could avoid having kids during hard times, having fewer kids means better survival outcomes for the children she does have, leading to more women being born with a roughly lunar length cycle.

snippet.textDisplay:
9:30 Dung beetles don`t eat dung - their larvae do.

They package the dung and bury it in brood tunnels to lay eggs into, one per exactly measured dung-pill, and the larvae thus have nourishment for the starting phase of their life.
The adults of nearly all families of dung beetles prefer fresh foliage or fungi as nourishment. Only exception are Taurocerastinae.
snippet.textOriginal:
9:30    Dung beetles don`t eat dung - their larvae do.

They package the dung and bury it in brood tunnels to lay eggs into, one per exactly measured dung-pill,  and the larvae thus have nourishment for the starting phase of their life.
The adults of nearly all families of dung beetles prefer fresh foliage or fungi as nourishment. Only exception are Taurocerastinae.

The same would hold true for the hunted, with hightened sense of fear. And we as humans have been both hunters as well as prey. Again it would be interesting to see if remnants of this does affect out state of mind durring lunar phases. Or it's all not. Just a theory.

snippet.textDisplay:
I have no personal experience with epilepsy; but if it was strictly the lower light level during the last quarter, then wouldn't there be more seizures at the dark of the moon, or in the first quarter, coming off the dark of the moon, rather than the last quarter, when we're coming off a full moon? Is it something to do with the drop in melatonin due to more light from the full moon, perhaps? Like if melatonin helps prevent them, then it would make sense that by the time we finally get around to the last quarter, one's levels would be the lowest, thanks to having gone through the full moon, and the build-up to it.


Which would mean that, historically speaking, one might not have more seizures during the full moon; but that it might herald a greater chance of them in the next few days, making it look like it was the moon causing the effect, if not necessarily immediately. But if it's the melatonin levels and their relationship to the levels of moonlight at the time, then it kind of does (as you said), which is intriguing.



That makes me wonder if there's a correlation between levels of light pollution and seizures. Do people have fewer seizures in rural areas? Would blackout curtains and a sleep mask lower the incidence of them in urban areas?


Fascinating topic!
snippet.textOriginal:
I have no personal experience with epilepsy; but if it was strictly the lower light level during the last quarter, then wouldn't there be more seizures at the dark of the moon, or in the first quarter, coming off the dark of the moon, rather than the last quarter, when we're coming off a full moon? Is it something to do with the drop in melatonin due to more light from the full moon, perhaps? Like if melatonin helps prevent them, then it would make sense that by the time we finally get around to the last quarter, one's levels would be the lowest, thanks to having gone through the full moon, and the build-up to it.


Which would mean that, historically speaking, one might not have more seizures *during* the full moon; but that it might herald a greater chance of them in the next few days, making it look like it was the moon causing the effect, if not necessarily immediately. But if it's the melatonin levels and their relationship to the levels of moonlight at the time, then it kind of does (as you said), which is intriguing.



That makes me wonder if there's a correlation between levels of light pollution and seizures. Do people have fewer seizures in rural areas? Would blackout curtains and a sleep mask lower the incidence of them in urban areas?


Fascinating topic!

snippet.textDisplay:
Regarding point one, I just recently wondered about full-moon related insomnia as my kid woke up at 2AM wanting to play.
I have I hypothesis - maybe full moon reflects not only visible light but also shorter wavelenghts such as UV? Maybe the excess of UV radiation during the night (most of our UV comes from the sun, so our bodies read UV - day, no UV - night) somehow messes up the synthesis of melatonin or just breaks our circadian rythm? That is actually a quite an interesting topic :)
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
So scorpions can't see UV light (tho neither can we) but they detect it with their shells and get the signal to hide.

We can't see infrared, but we feel it on our skin as heat. So our body tells us when to avoid infrared light and seek cooler areas.

Is say there was some convergent evolution, there.

snippet.textDisplay:
The whole 'epilepsy and moon' thing also appears in the ancient Mesopotamian material, in which the moon-god Nannar-Su'en is considered to be the ruler over epilepsy. When he's in his full light, the epilepsy-demon is not around as much.

Pretty cool that that seems to be confirmed by modern science! 😎 Ancient people weren't as stupid as many think
snippet.textOriginal:
The whole 'epilepsy and moon' thing also appears in the ancient Mesopotamian material, in which the moon-god Nannar-Su'en is considered to be the ruler over epilepsy. When he's in his full light, the epilepsy-demon is not around as much. 

Pretty cool that that seems to be confirmed by modern science! 😎 Ancient people weren't as stupid as many think

snippet.textDisplay:
Circolunar rhythm would explain why stats collected by the emergency services in the UK have shown that crimes & injuries (usually related to crime, such as drunken behaviour being worse & tipping over into crime) do increase on nights when there's a full moon. Mental health issues also tend to flare up on a full moon too. I come from a medical background & have retired police officers & a serving police officer in my family & we have all observed this happening. It's not a myth.
Part of my medical background comes from working in the neurophysiology department of a top UK children's hospital where they test for seizures & their different types. The melatonin theory may be right to some degree. The reason we would test for seizures by getting the patient to sleep is because they are more prone to seizure activity when they're sleeping or tired. Therefore, although (as a health scientist) I believe that melatonin may play a part, I think there are also other factors at play too.
snippet.textOriginal:
Circolunar rhythm would explain why stats collected by the emergency services in the UK have shown that crimes & injuries (usually related to crime, such as drunken behaviour being worse & tipping over into crime) do increase on nights when there's a full moon. Mental health issues also tend to flare up on a full moon too. I come from a medical background & have retired police officers & a serving police officer in my family & we have all observed this happening. It's not a myth.
Part of my medical background comes from working in the neurophysiology department of a top UK children's hospital where they test for seizures & their different types. The melatonin theory may be right to some degree. The reason we would test for seizures by getting the patient to sleep is because they are more prone to seizure activity when they're sleeping or tired. Therefore, although (as a health scientist) I believe that melatonin may play a part, I think there are also other factors at play too.

snippet.textDisplay: My grandmother didn’t believe in the full moon making people crazy until she started working in a nursing home with people with Alzheimer’s & dementia. After that she believed in it for the rest of her life. My aunt is nurse & works in the maternity ward & she says there is so many more births during the full moon. & my mom is a pharmacy technician & she worked in a hospital for 19 years & saw first hand how much more crazy people got during the full moon. Now she works at a Sam’s Club pharmacy & she says costumers get crazier during the full moon. The stories she has omg 😳 so, sorry, but I whole heartedly believe there is a correlation between the full moon & peoples behavior. I also have 2 other family members (a cousin & uncle) who are nurses so I know so many people that have seen the effects of the full moon on people to not believe it. It’s crazy. Also if people aren’t getting as much sleep as usual, it’s not that surprising that people would act crazier during full moons. Also my other grandmother recently passed away 2 months ago. She had dementia & I just looked up the moon cycles from that time. There was a full moon when she started getting sicker. She had a big scare on Monday November 11th & I know this cause that was exactly 2 weeks before she died. The last time I saw her was actually during a full moon on Tuesday November 12th (I know cause I rushed to see her the next day after the scare) & she was acting very strange to say the least. I know part of it was all the drugs she was on but I’d never seen her act that strange before, even when she was on drugs before. She was saying the strangest things & my uncle was there with me by coincidence (I got out of school the same time he got off work & showed up at the same time) & even he didn’t know wtf she was talking about. I can’t even describe it. It was like she was in this other world where she had been taken hostage?...& tied up?....& held down?... & dragged out?...I have no idea. & she was saying she hadn’t slept it days (she’d been asleep all day the day before because of the scare so the hospice nurses gave her a bunch of morphine to knock her out so they could work on trying to save her) & she did NOT want to eat, she was adamant on going to bed (it was like 4:30pm) to the point she was starting to get angry (her familiar angry voice that I hadn’t heard since before the dementia was coming out). Now I’d heard her say “i haven’t slept in days” before & knew it wasnt true cause usually all she did during my visits was sleep. But I’d never seen her so adamant about going to bed RIGHT NOW & refusing to eat like that & about to throw a fit (my uncle & I left before it got ugly 😬) It was scary & so sad to for me & my uncle to see. My uncle & I just kept looking at each other like “what is happening???” & I hadn’t seen her that talkative in years. Usually all she did was sleep. She actually passed away on Monday November 25th & Tuesday November 26th was a new moon so 👀 idk it’s all so strange.

She was saying the strangest things & my uncle was there with me by coincidence (I got out of school the same time he got off work & showed up at the same time) & even he didn’t know wtf she was talking about. I can’t even describe it. It was like she was in this other world where she had been taken hostage?...& tied up?....& held down?... & dragged out?...I have no idea. & she was saying she hadn’t slept it days (she’d been asleep all day the day before because of the scare so the hospice nurses gave her a bunch of morphine to knock her out so they could work on trying to save her) & she did NOT want to eat, she was adamant on going to bed (it was like 4:30pm) to the point she was starting to get angry (her familiar angry voice that I hadn’t heard since before the dementia was coming out). Now I’d heard her say “i haven’t slept in days” before & knew it wasnt true cause usually all she did during my visits was sleep. But I’d never seen her so adamant about going to bed RIGHT NOW & refusing to eat like that & about to throw a fit (my uncle & I left before it got ugly 😬) It was scary & so sad to for me & my uncle to see. My uncle & I just kept looking at each other like “what is happening???” & I hadn’t seen her that talkative in years. Usually all she did was sleep. She actually passed away on Monday November 25th & Tuesday November 26th was a new moon so 👀 idk it’s all so strange.

snippet.textDisplay: It makes sense. When a full moon is out there is more light to see and so we can do more at night. And so anyone that naturally took advantage of it by sleeping a bit less were likely more successful and so past down their genes moore. And that is why we still have this left over from our animal ancestors even to this day.
